Garment production hit by strike.description: COIMBATORE: The strike by the Tirupur Power Table Owners’ Association demanding a charter of demands entered the fifth day on Sunday, bringing production of garments worth lakhs of rupees to a halt and leaving many jobless, though temporarily. Pointing out that they had been stitching garments for a private company in Tirupur by employing hundreds of workers, Murugasen, joint secretary of the association, said, “The company settles just 65% of the bill amount at a time and it takes several months to pay the remaining amount. How is it possible for us to pay the workers and manage other expenditures with half the bill amount? We had escalated the issue several times, but to no avail.” The central government levies 5% goods and service tax (GST) on all the job works. “How could we alter the GST? It is uniform for all the job works across the country,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Polluting industrial unit downs shutter.description: COIMBATORE: Days after the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) sought explanation from a private company in Malumichampatti, which was found discharging untreated industrial effluents, the firm was found closed. “Based on a complaint from a farmers’ association, we inspected the electroplating company and found it discharging effluents into a chock pit and polluting soil and water. It had not obtained license from TNPCB,” an official said. Equipment were removed from the company premises and the company was found closed. “They have closed the company on their own. But they still have to give a reply and based on it, final decision will be taken,” the official said. TOI had carried a report explaining how the company, which is situated amid farmlands, had been polluting underground water and soil. “The company, surrounded by farmlands for over 50 acres, began functioning just a couple of months ago. Initially, there weren’t any issues. Locals noticed the company releasing untreated industrial effluents that had traces of chromium. After we raised questions, they dug a chock pit started to discharge the effluents into the pit,” said V Vishnusankar, a farmer. Farmers in the area had blamed the firm after crops including banana plants started to wither. “A borewellthe only source of water to the entire villageis situation just a few hundred metres from the company,” Vishnusankar said. The TNPCB official said that they were yet to receive a reply from the company and based on the reply, action would be taken. “Permission will not be given to run a company amid agricultural land,” he added. Medicines supplied to govt health centre.description: TIRUPUR: Ion tablets, medicines used in oral rehydration threapy, and other drugs distributed in government health centres and hospitals were found dumped at Alangiyam near Dharapuram here on Monday. Health officials said the medicines, which were not expired, were mostly given to pregnant women. While they were yet to ascertain why the medicines were dumped, they found that the medicines were from the batches supplied to district health centres. The district administration has ordered inquiry into the issue. Locals, who noticed the medicines at a graveyard adjacent to a water pumping station near Amaravathi River, informed the authorities. District health department officials along with police reached the spot, collected the dumped medicines and sent them to the primary health centre at Ponnapuram. Jayanthi Somasundaram, deputy director of health services, Tirupur, said, “We have started inquiry into the issue. We are in contact with the Tamil Nadu Medical Services Corporation to find out the batches to which the medicines belonged. We are verifying medicine stocks in health sub centres and primary health centres.” When contacted, Dharapuram sub-collector Pavankumar G Giriyappanavar told TOI, “We have been informed about the dumping. We will take appropriate action against people who are responsible for it.” Since the dumped medicines posed threat to environment and loss to the exchequer, it has caused outrage among the people in the area. Tejasvi Surya.description: BENGALURU: From a boy who was groomed by late Union minister H N Ananth Kumar and Tejaswini Ananth Kumar to becoming the challenge to the family’s control over Bengaluru South segment, Tejasvi Surya has come a long way.While expressing his gratitude to Kumar and his family, Surya says he is a stark example of the BJP’s intent to infuse young and new blood. You were a surprise choice for Bengaluru South. Did you expect this development?While I had feelers that there was something like this going around, I was quite happily savouring pani puri with my friends. To be honest I was overwhelmed and started tweeting about this. I only feel gratitude towards the party, which is facing a crucial election and has decided to take risk by fielding a youngster in such a prestigious seat. At 28, will you be able to fill the shoes of Kumar?Filling the shoes of Ananth Kumar is a far fetched thing for he was so gigantic. I only pray to God to give me strength, sincerity and earnestness to honestly work for the people of this constituency so that one day in the eyes of the people I can match up to Kumar’s contribution to the constituency. On lack of political experience, I have a well oiled party organisational machinery to support me with senior leaders there to hand hold me. So what is this election going to be for you?Primarily it is an election for PM Narendra Modi’s aspirational India. It is about the promise of a new and young India and I am just an ambassador of the message of this new India. It is a reflection of party and Modi’s inclination of bringing in young blood. Tejaswini not getting the ticket is quite sensitive...Yes it is sensitive but even during her talk with the Karyakartas she told them that the it was time to show maturity. She has given her full support to me. But what is your personal opinion about Tejaswini missing the ticket?When her name was first finalised by the state leadership, it must be March 11, I was the first to extend my support to her and remember posting on social media that she was the most deserving candidate and a good choice from the constituency. But the party decided to field an ordinary karyakarta like me. It is a decision taken by big people and I am just a foot soldier obeying their diktat. I have always supported Tejaswini ma’am and was literally groomed by that family. I have no reason for acrimony. Statements by Karti Chidamabaram suggest that you are the Schutzstaffel of BJP, or the infamous SS of the Nazi Germany... Your tweets also suggest that your idealogical beliefs are in conflict with the “Sab Ka Saath Sab Ka Vikas” For Karti Chidambaram and others I will reply back to them in their own coin. The idealogical inclinations are not an issue for this election. The issue for the election today, is PM Modi’s promise of a new and superpower India. My only concern as on today is to ensure that Bangalore South elects the BJP with a massive margin so that we will strengthen Modi hands. Rest is immaterial. Is age an advantage or do you require time to project yourself as a leader?That the party leadership has reposed faith in me speaks for itself and the least minimum I can do is to live up to it and say I am capable enough as on today to take on these challenges. You must rise to the occasion and I will rise to it. On dynasty politics, considering you are a nephew of a sitting BJP MLA and PM Modi has gone on the offensive against the Congress on the issue of “Naamdar”...My candidature and my role and activity in politics has no connection to my uncle’s political life. I have an identity of my own and have worked very hard over years. My aspirations precedes his elections. If the party leadership thought I was a rise to another dynast, they would not have considered me at all. Pawan Kalyan.description: GUNTUR: Stating that they will bulldoze bastions of TDP and YSR Congress, Janasena president Pawan Kalyan promised to grant Rs 5,000 pension to all farmers in the state. He said they will also grant Rs 8,000 crop incentive to farmers soon after coming into power in the next elections. Pawan further said his government would provide six to 10 LPG cylinders free-of-cost to each family every year. and also promised to fill 3 lakh vacancies in the government departments to provide jobs to youth. Addressing a meeting in Guntur on Monday, Pawan said that the future of the state did not mean the future of Lokesh and Jagan but it was the future of the people. “The space on the state’s political stage is not TDP’s and YSRC’s property as youth and women are eager to bring change through Jana Sena.” “TDP had lost moral right to rule the state as chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu had no control over his legislators who indulged in illegal activities,” Pawan said adding that he jumped into the political arena to bring in a change in the lives of commoners. “We supported TDP and BJP in the last elections with a hope to transform the state. Unfortunately, both of them have shattered our dreams,” he said. “Guntur city has been left in a lurch despite located a few kilometres away from the capital city. The entire city has been dug out in the guise of laying underground drainage scheme and left without repair. How shocking it is to see 30 people dying of diarrhoea in a city like Guntur? Is it not the failure of the state government? Opposition leader Jaganmohan Reddy is equally responsible for the tragedy as he never dared to question the government by going to the assembly,” he said. He further said they would construct apartments exclusively for Muslims in the city. He appealed to people to support his candidates Chandrasekhar (Guntur West), Zia-Ur-Rehman (East) and MP candidate Bonaboina Srinivas Yadav in the elections, Pawan said they fielded a BC candidate Srinivasa Yadav whereas TDP and YSRC both have given tickets to their own communities. Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani. Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. NGO helps dropouts to return to school.description: COIMBATORE: Thanks to the efforts of Vizhuthugal Organization, an NGO, over 200 school dropouts from the rural parts of the western districts are continuing education. “With the help of volunteers and women self-help groups, we identified over 200 school dropouts in the villages of Annur block in Coimbatore, Avinashi block in Tirupur and Nambiyur block in Erode and took measures to send them back to schools. The students were constantly monitored to ensure that they do not drop out again,” said M Thangavel, director of the organization. Compared to girls in rural areas, it is the boys, who are often forced to quit schools. More than 65% of the dropouts from the blocks were boys, Thangavel said. “To understand the reasons behind it, we conducted a study in the blocks. We chose the blocks as several child marriages were reported from there. Child labour was also rampant at these three places.” “We had selected 20 villages in Nambiyur block and started children resource centres (CRC) in each village to assist the children two years ago. Apart from guiding them through their academic syllabus, other assistance like counselling and life skill guidance were given to them. In the last two years, no child marriage, no child labour and no school dropouts were reported from those villages,” Thangavel said. The NGO has now identified 60 villages to launch the CRCs. “The main reason for dropout among boys is the poor financial situation in their families. After a certain age, they would be encouraged to work rather than study. Initially, it took us a lot of time to convince the parents, but eventually they accepted and started sending their children to schools. Now, many of the them are in colleges,” said S Vidhya, a facilitator from Ekalikovilmedu village in Nambiyur block. Many parents assume that the schools would not admit their wards if they are absent for three months and do not make any attempt to admit them again, Vidhya said. “Everything else would fall in place if enough awareness is created.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BJP List 2019 Tamilnadu.description: CHENNAI: The BJP's Tamil Nadu candidates list announced on Thursday was on expected lines, with Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan being fielded from Kanyakumari, state chief Tamilisai Soundararajan in Tuticorin, national secretary H Raja in Sivaganga, C P Radhakrishnan in Coimbatore and vice-president Nainar Nagendran in Ramanathapuram. While Pon Radhakrishnan and Raja will fight Congress, which is yet to name candidates for its nine seats in DMK alliance, Tamilisai will cross swords with DMK heavyweight Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. H Raja to contest from Sivaganga for third timeH Raja is contesting from Sivaganga for the third time. In 2014, he came third with 1.33 lakh votes, while in 1999, he came second. It will be a keenly fought battle between Tamilisai and DMK’s state women wing secretary and Rajya Sabha MP K Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. Though Tamilisai initially preferred to contest from Chennai South, which has a sizeable votebank for the party, she finally settled for Tuticorin. AIADMK was keen on retaining south Chennai for sitting MP, J Jayavardhan, son of fisheries minister D Jayakumar. Former TN BJP chief Radhakrishnan will face CPM’s P R Natarajan in Coimbatore. This is the fifth time that Radhakrishnan has been fielded in Coimbatore, a BJP stronghold. While he won two consecutive Lok Sabha elections in 1998 and 1999, he was defeated in the 2004 and 2014 polls. Nainar Nagendran has been pitted against DMK’s IUML candidate K Nawaz Kani. While the party made a quick decision on candidates for four constituencies, Ramanathapuram delayed matters considering the keen contest for the seat among some senior leaders. Rural police rope in CIT to study accide.description: COIMBATORE: Professors and students of Coimbatore Institute of Technology (CIT) will come out with a detailed report about accident spots in rural Coimbatore and measures to be taken to curb fatal accidents on these spots. The Coimbatore rural police have roped in CIT to conduct a study about fatal accidents in its limit. The professors along with students will visit accident spots and traffic bottlenecks in Pollachi, Mettupalayam, Thudiyalur, Annur, Karumathampatti and Sulur areas. District superintendent of police Sujit Kumar said the team will visit various accident spots in the district and will interact with the motorists and shopkeepers in the localities. A team, led by dean of student affairs Dr S Shanmugam, will visit Karumathampatti on June 19 as part of the study. The team will be accompanied by deputy superintendent of police, Karumathampatti sub-division, inspector of police and sub-inspectors of police from Karumathampatti police. Assistant professor of department of civil engineering J Cyril Santhosh will also be part of the team. “The professors and their teams will be taken to accident spots by police officers. The professors will study the reasons for accidents and will interact with the motorists. They will also suggest short-term and long-term solutions to control fatal accidents. Likewise, the professors and their teams will visit the entire districts to identify accident spots. We expect that they would submit their report within a month,” Sujit Kumar said. He said the report will also be shared with the national highways, state highways and local body. “We can reduce the fatal accidents by join efforts with other departments. If the report suggests installing a street lamp to provide lighting facilities, we will send the report to the respective authorities,” Sujit Kumar said. He said the detailed report will help the rural police to control accidents rates in the district. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

76-year-old Tamil Nadu school reopens fo.description: COIMBATORE: The Adi Dravidar and Tribal Welfare Department has reopened its 76-year-old elementary school at Chinnakallar in Valparai for just one student. After educating one girl student during 2017-18, the school was temporarily closed because of zero enrolment. Rajeshwari, a worker at a tea estate at Chinnakallar, wanted to admit her six-year-old son Shiva to the nearby school, but was upset as the school in her locality was closed and the Adi Dravidar Welfare School at Periyakallar was 4km away. She requested the officials to reopen the school and admit her son, and, much to her astonishment, the officials accepted her request. “Shiva was admitted in Class I on Monday based on a request from his mother. I was given additional duty to take care of the school and teach the kid. The department has taken special efforts to open the school,” said M Sakthivel, headmaster of the school at Periyakallar. He said the headmaster and teacher were transferred to other schools about a year ago. “The school was opened in 1943 to educate students of tea estate workers in the locality, as over 300 workers lived there. The school functioned for over 70 years, educating more than 50 students every year. It lost its shine in the past few years as workers started to migrate to other regions,” said an official from the department. Speaking about the frequency of elephant attacks and animal menace, as Chinnakallar is located in a dense forest, the official said the number of families residing in the region has drastically reduced to 15. “In 2017-18, we kept the school open with a teacher and head master just for one student. After this, no student was willing to enroll as elephants began roaming in the area, even breaking the window and doors of the school, said another senior official from the department. “At present, no such attack has taken place in the locality. But the threat is there. As the family is from the same locality and is used to elephant visits, they are not scared. Still, we have been trying to convince his mother to move her son to the school at Periyakallar. If she agrees, the school would be closed,” he added. BSP List 2019 UP.description: LUCKNOW: The BSP on Friday announced its first list of 11 candidates for the Lok Sabha elections 2019, fielding JD(S) turncoat Kunwar Danish Ali from Amroha. Ali, who was general secretary of the Janata Dal-Secular, quit the party and joined the Bahujan Samaj Party only last week. The BSP also declared Haji Fazulrahman its nominee from Saharanpur, Malook Nagar from Bijnore and Girish Chandra from Nagina, a party release said. Hazi Mohammad Yakoob has been fielded from Meerut, Satbeer Nagar from Gautam Buddh Nagar, Yogesh Verma from Bulandshahr, Ajit Baliyan from Aligarh, Manoj Kumar Soni from Agra, Rajveer Singh from Fatehpur Sikri and Ruchi Veera from Aonla. Mayawati's BSP is contesting 38 of the 80 Lok Sabha constituencies in Uttar Pradesh under the seat-sharing arrangement with Samajwadi Party and the Rashtriya Lok Dal. Private school to help poor students re.description: TIRUPUR: A private school in Udumalpet in the district has come forward to support the civil service aspirants, who have cleared preliminary examinations, financially. “Hundreds of young people, who are coming from humble backgrounds, are struggling to pursue their civil service dreams due to lack of financial support. We wanted to do our bit to support a few of them financially,” said S Ananda Krishnan of T R Narayanasamy Naidu and Sons Charities, which runs the Srinivasa Vidhyalaya Matric Higher Secondary School in Udumalpet . He said they have decided to distribute Rs 25,000 each to at least 10 aspirants, who have cleared either preliminary examinations of Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) Group 1 or Union Public Service Commission (combined civil services). “The scholarship will focus on aspirants from rural areas and those who have studied in government and aided schools. Students from Tirupur, Coimbatore and Dindigul districts will be given preference.” Ananda Krishnan said the school would also help the aspirants with the travelling, lodging, food and coaching centre expenses during the preparation of examinations. “The eligible aspirants can approach our trust and we will verify their details before extending our support. This is for the first time we are introducing the scholarship this year and we may continue it in the coming years too,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Coimbatore awaits mortal remains of air.description: COIMBATORE: “Mom, I would rather wear this t-shirt in front of you, when I am at home, than on my birthday, when I will be away,” said Air Force squadron leader Vinod Hariharan, when his mother Thangamani showed him the gift she had bought for his 31st birthday, which falls on July 22. Vinod was one among the 13 IAF personnel killed in the military aircraft crash in Arunachal Pradesh on June 3. After a month-long vacation in May, Vinod was eager to fly back to Jorhat airbase in Assam. His cousins dropped him at the Air Force airport here. Once he reached, he sent a text message saying he reached safely. He called his mother again saying that he was raring to join duty. Thangamani's world fell apart when she was informed that the wreckage of the flight her son was in was found and no one survived the crash. Vinod, whose family had settled in Singanallur from Kerala more than a decade ago, was a student of the Kumaraguru College of Technology. Joining the Indian Air Force was a natural progression for Vinod, said his cousin Vijayan. “As their father was in the defence as an accountant and they were students of Kendriya Vidyalaya, Vinod and his elder brother never had any doubt about their future. Joining the Army, Navy or the Air Force was a natural choice for them. He chose to follow his older brother, who had joined the Air Force during 2008-09,” Vijayan told TOI. Vinod joined the Air Force in 2010-11 and was posted in Kochi, Agra, Jorhat and Sulur stations. He was involved in the IAF’s Kerala flood rescue operations last year. “He was very fond of his wife, who he had married two-and-a-half year ago and took very good care of his mother,” Vijayan said. During his vacation, Vinod gifted his mother a new two-wheeler. “We are yet to register it,” said Vijayan. The family is now left with the sweet memories they shared with Vinod during his last vacation last month. “We watched a few world cup matches together. He was a huge cricket fan. The whole family got together, played music, danced and played card games till 3am. We still can’t believe that he is not with us. He was a soft-spoken, jovial man but also very brave.” The whole family has gathered at the house to give Thangamani company during the agonizing wait for her son’s remains. “The Air Force has still not given us a definitive date. They said it would depend on the weather at that mountain range. We hope it will arrive either on Sunday or early next week,” Vijayan added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Elephant herd blocking road, rail traffi.description: UDHAGAMANDALAM: A herd of nine elephants, including two tuskers and three calves, has been disrupting traffic on Coonoor-Mettupalayam road and the Nilgiri Moutain Railway track at Runnymede for the past two days. Forest officials have been taking measures to chase the animals away into the forest, but in vain. According to the residents of Kattery area, the elephant herd was seen near Kattery junction on Coonoor-Mettupalayam road two days ago. The elephants blocked traffic until forest officials came and chased them away. “We chased the elephants away into the forest area. But they came to Runnymede area the next day. We are monitoring their movement and taking measures to chase them deep inside the forest,” said a forest official. On Saturday, the same herd strayed into Nanjappa Chattiram in Coonoor. “The elephants are invading the town area and it is a cause for concern. The forest department should take a concrete measure to track their movement and prevent them from entering Coonoor town,” said a local resident. The forest official, meanwhile, said a team had been formed to monitor the movement of the herd. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Swachh Bharat subsidy: Block co-ordinato.description: COIMBATORE: Acting on TOI reports, Palladam block development officer (BDO) S Balamurugan terminated block co-ordinator K Maheshwari from service for collecting bribe from the residents of Ichipatti village to facilitate subsidy for constructing toilets under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. The termination order was issued on Saturday. Panchayat secretary Suresh Kumar, who was working at the panchayat in 2016, was also suspended for failing to monitor and control such activities in his panchayat. A senior official from the district rural development agency (DRDA) said, “In 2016, Maheshwari was in charge of identifying the households without toilets and assisting the villagers to construct a toilet under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan scheme. Motivator Sathya was in charge of motivating the public to join the scheme. But they had collected Rs 1,500 - Rs 2,000 per house as bribe and promised them to get a government subsidy of Rs 12,000 for each toilet. Believing their words, the villagers constructed the toilets by taking loans. But the villagers never got the government subsidy. All these came out during an inquiry conducted by the BDO after TOI reported about the scam on June 11.” “It is also proved that the bribe amount - Rs 1.48 lakh - which Maheshwari distributed to 87 villagers on June 13 was her own money and not the incentive amount of Sathya as she claimed. Sathya was dismissed one and half years ago,” the official added. The block co-ordinator and motivator are temporary posts filled by BDO, who has powers to terminate them. In its report on June 11, TOI revealed that over 100 residents of Ichipatti village near Palladam in Tirupur were waiting for the subsidy for more than three years after constructing household toilets by taking loans. Though the original scheme envisages funding – subsidy of Rs 12,000 per toilet - at various stages of construction, the prospective beneficiaries had to beg and borrow to construct toilets as the officials had only promised to reimburse the expenditure once the facility is ready. Ola drivers stage protest in Coimbatore.description: COIMBATORE: Around 200 drivers who work for private cab aggregator Ola staged a demonstration in front of its office at R S Puram here to protest a cut in salaries. The drivers said the company had been paying them almost Rs 23,000 per month. Now they are paid Rs 13,000 per month. The protesters entered the Ola office premises and continued their protest. As a result of the protest, many people who tried booking Ola cabs in the suburbs ended up facing delays and cancellations, forcing them to look for other options. The drivers said they had been receiving a reduced salary for the past two months and so they could not run their families with it. “We are employees who take vehicles on lease from Ola and pay the lease amount periodically. We also used to earn a bonus for driving 12 hours a day. With the bonus itself amounting to Rs 300 to Rs 400 a day, we could pay the lease amount of Rs 800 per day and still take home around Rs 900 per day or Rs 23,000 a month,” said a protester named Balaji. “However, for the past two months, we have been getting a bonus of Rs 50 to Rs 100 a day, so after paying the lease amount, we hardly get Rs 500 a day which is insufficient to run our families,” he said. Ola officials in Coimbatore were not available for comment despite multiple attempts by TOI. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AMMK Candidate List 2019.description: CHENNAI: AMMK deputy general secretary TTV Dhinakaran on Friday released the second and final list of candidates - 14 for the Lok Sabha polls and 9 for assembly bypoll in Tamil Nadu. The party has decided to field two of its heavyweight disqualified MLAs to contest Lok Sabha polls and to take on strong candidates from AIADMK alliance. Disqualified MLA from Andipatti and AMMK propaganda secretary, Thanga Tamilselvan, has been fielded from Theni Lok Sabha constituency, he will take on P Ravindranath Kumar, son of deputy chief minister and AIADMK coordinator O Paneerselvam. Disqualified MLA from Paapireddipatti and former minister P Palaniappan will be contesting the Lok Sabha polls from Dharmapuri constituency. He will take on PMK youth wing leader and former Union health minister Anbumani Ramadoss, who is contesting on behalf of the AIADMK-BJP-PMK alliance.| Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in Tamil NaduBesides these two, AMMK has also selected another disqualified MLA, NG Parthibhan from Sholingar assembly segment, to contest Arakonam Lok Sabha constituency. He will take on former Unions minister of state S Jagathrakshakan of the DMK - Congress alliance on the seat. AMMK had earlier released its first list of 24 candidates for Lok Sabha and 9 candidates for assembly bypoll in the state last Sunday. Dhinakaran will release the party's manifesto for the Lok Sabha polls later during the day. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Children\u2019s ICU begins functioning a.description: COIMBATORE: An advanced intensive care unit for children, which was inaugurated last month, began functioning at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital here on Monday. The children’s ICU, which will provide a more sanitized ambience for critical care and a lesser risk of infections, has been set up in the first floor of the old CT scan building. It is equipped with 16 beds, each of which can be remotely operated and offer five different positions. “This will make children more comfortable while they are being made to undergo various procedures, like tube feeding, inserting a ventilator among others. Each bed has also been equipped with oxygen, suction facilities and equipment to monitor vitals,” GH dean Dr B Ashokan said. Earlier the children’s ICU was functioning in a portion of the pediatric surgical unit. Children above the age of one usually require intensive care if they suffer from a severe infection that has progressed to septicemia, severe asthmatic attacks or generally any infection that affects their respiratory tract. “Since children’s trachea and bronchi are very tiny, severe infections like encephalitis or the flu immediately leads to breathing and oxygen intake issues, which sometimes need oxygen or ventilator,” the dean said. The hospital serves children from at least four nearby districts. They come with different types of severe infections, which progresses to septicemia before they are referred to us, the dean said. Private hospitals charge Rs 20,000 a day for the same facilities, while in GH its free, he said. The space for the ward was handed over to Rotary Club of Satellite, who roped in two private firms—Aquasub and Jewel one— and raised Rs 1.2 crore. They built the ward and handed it over back to GH. Tamil Nadu college student held for murd.description: TIRUPUR: Police arrested a 20-year-old college student near Avinashi in Tirupur district of Tamil Nadu for murdering his cousin. Police said J Francis Vallarasu of Thondi in Ramanathapuram district murdered his cousin, A Augustine from Sivaganga district, by hitting him on his head with an iron rod when the latter told him that he would tell his father about his bad habits, including smoking. Francis, his father K Jesurasu, 49, and Augustine were staying in a house at Kasigoundenpudur near Avinashi. While Francis and Augustine were studying in a private college at Neelipalayam, Jesurasu was working in a hotel, said a police officer. The murder came to light on Friday evening when Jesurasu returned home after work. On being informed, the Avinashi police recovered the body and sent it for postmortem. Francis, who was absconding after murdering Augustine, was arrested on Saturday and remanded in judicial custody. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

1 in 6 above age of 40 suffer from overa.description: Coimbatore: ‘I laughed so hard I wet my pants’ is not an expression anymore but a harsh reality, especially for women, say urologists.Urologists in the city estimate that one in six people over the age of 40 suffer from an “overactive bladder” and the incidence increases with age. In this year’s ‘World Continence Week’, which is observed from June 17 to June 23, the theme is ‘incontinence is no laughing matter’. An overactive bladder (OAB), once considered a medical condition affecting the elderly population, is now being seen among younger men and women. “Overactive bladder is a problem where the bladder-storage functions become impaired, resulting in a sudden urge to urinate. In some cases, the urge may be so strong that it can result in leaks before you can reach the bathroom,” urologist at city-based Vedanayagam Hospital Dr Ganesh Gopalakrishnan said. “If you’re using the bathroom more than about eight times in 24-hour and if the urge keeps increasing, this could be a sign that there is something wrong,” he said. Some patients, with OAB, experience leakages when they laugh, sneeze or even jump because it puts pressure on the bladder. “Most people who suffer from urinary incontinence live with it because they believe there is nothing they can do about it,” urologist at GKNM Hospital Dr K S Vengetesh said. “However, people hesitate to discuss it with doctors due to embarrassment. It often leads to low self-esteem and social isolation,” a doctor said. However, another urologist said patients need to be aware that an overactive bladder is a common medical condition and can be treated or managed well. “With OAB, the bladder works overtime, contracting more often than it should and at inappropriate times. The bladder muscles seem to give wrong messages to the brain causing the bladder to feel fuller than it is. The bladder contracts too early when the bladder is not very full,” Dr C L Dinakaran of Arun Urology Hospital said. OAB can be managed with lifestyle changes, diet, medication and even surgery. “It is advisable to limit your caffeine intake, refrain from alcohol and spicy food,” Dr Vengetesh said. Thieves strike at two temples in Tirupur.description: TIRUPUR: An unidentified four-member gang attempted to steal a bronze idol from Alagumalai Murugan temple near Palladam in the district on Sunday night. But they managed to take away only a few other properties, including speakers. Police said the four reached the hill temple through staircases, broke two CCTV cameras and entered the temple wearing helmets. “They tried to break open the main door, but in vain. So, they could not take away the bronze Murugan idol. They, however, stole speakers and broke open a door at the back of the temple, which was locked from inside, to escape from the spot,” a police officer said. The Avinashipalayam police registered a case based on a complaint from the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment officials, who also urged police to increase night patrolling to prevent such incidents. In another instance, another gang attempted to rob Panchaloha Kalasam at Mahaliamman temple at Nachipalayam in Kavutthampalayam panchayat near Kunnathur on Monday. “They managed to remove one of three kalasams from the temple’s gopuram. But it apparently fell into an empty 70-feet well, and the miscreants fled,” a police officer attached to the Kunnathur police said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Farmers protesting power transmission to.description: COIMBATORE: At least 11 farmers were arrested for protesting against the high-voltage power transmission tower project near Annur here on Saturday. According to police, the farmers obstructed Power Grid Corporation of India officials, who visited the spot for surveying the land, from carrying out their work. Fellow farmers and villagers, however, said they would continue the protest. The project implemented by the Power Grid corporation of India at a cost of around Rs24,000 crore envisages erection of about 4,500 transmission towers from Raigarh in Chattisgarh to Pugalur in Karur district for a distance of 1,800km and then to Thrissur via Tirupur and Coimbatore. Farmers from all the districts, where the transmission towers would be installed on farmlands, have been opposing the project. Farmers said the project would not only take away their land but also leave adjoining tracts of cultivable land unfit for agriculture. There was a lull in protests, but it seems to have gathered momentum with the officials resuming land survey for erection of the towers. On June 11, a team of Power Grid Corporation officials had visited Karumathampatti, Semmandampalayam, Vaickapalayam and nearby areas, where the farmers put up a stiff resistance and staged protest. The officials once again visited Semmandampalayam on Saturday, forcing farmers to stage another protest. The farmers were arrested, taken to a marriage hall and released later in the day. Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Old answer scripts on truck spill on roa.description: COIMBATORE: Old answer scripts from the Anna University Regional Campus at Navavoor on the Maruthamalai Main Road in Coimbatore, which were being carried on a truck to be weighed and pulped, spilled on the road at Vadavalli here on Monday morning. M Saravanakumar, dean of the campus, said the answer scripts were more than a year old and were being taken to the Tamil Nadu Newsprint and Papers Limited (TNPL) at Karur to be pulped. He said as per the government norms, nullified answer scripts - that are more than a year old - should be taken to TNPL for pulping. When the papers were being carried by the truck, they spilled on the road at Vadavalli in the city. A mini truck was brought to the spot, and a portion of the papers were transferred to it and then taken away. Sources said the papers were not loaded properly on the truck, which might have caused the mishap. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Massive tree plantation drive to ensure.description: COIMBATORE: The District Rural Development Agency (DRDA) is all set to launch a massive tree plantation scheme in Tirupur district, under which survival of 1.20lakh saplings will be ensured with the help of farmers, who have set up drip irrigation system in their land. “We have been planting saplings along roads, near ponds and on public land under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) to increase green cover. As it is difficult to water and protect the saplings from stray cattle, the survival rate was very low. MGNREGA workers could not be used to water the saplings after 100 days of work. As a result, we used to lose almost half of the plants. Saplings planted near ponds would be submerged during the rainy reasons,” an official said. The survival rate will be high in farmlands, which are fenced and equipped with drip irrigation, the official said. “While MGNREGA workers would be used to dig pits and plant the saplings, farmers will water and protect the saplings. We have decided to plant fruit trees like sapota and mangoes and herbal plants in farmlands,” she said. The scheme is expected to attract farmers, who are hesitating to invest in agriculture. “They need not spend money to buy the saplings and to plant them. DRDA will take care of it. The farmers will get ownership over the plants and can sell the fruits in future. Those interested in the scheme should get in touch with block-level officials,” the official added. DRDA had spent only Rs 1.39crore out of the Rs 2crore allotted to plant saplings near ponds in Avinashi block during 201617. Saplings were not planted near two ponds in Thamaraikulam panchayats due to drought. A lion’s share of the money was used to pay wages to the workers. DMK members stage protest in Coimbatore.description: COIMBATORE: Police on Wednesday detained 512 DMK members, including Singanallur legislator N Karthik, for protesting in front of the Coimbatore City Municipal Corporation (CCMS) office. Of them, 118 were women. They were demanding regular distribution of drinking water. Karthik announced the protest earlier this week. On Wednesday morning, police denied permission for it. However, the members staged a protest despite that. They were detained and were lodged in a marriage hall. Karthik said they had protested demanding water supply once in three to four days. “Also, we seek resignation of minister for municipal administration S P Velumani as he has not taken proactive measures to handle the water situation,” he said. They also protested the municipal body giving the water supply rights to a private firm. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Nilgiris founder remembered.description: UDHAGAMANDALAM: The district administration on Saturday arranged a function to mark the 231st birth anniversary of John Sullivan, the founder of modern Nilgiris. Nilgiris collector J Innocent Divya garlanded the bust of Sullivan erected in front of the Sullivan Memorial, the very first building in the Nilgiris located at Kannerimukku village, 2km away from Kotagiri. Villagers from nearby areas attended the function. Sullivan, who was born on June 15, 1788, was attached to the East India Company. He arrived in India in 1803 and went on to become the collector of Coimbatore in 1817. Sullivan explored the Nilgiris during 1819 and laid the foundation stone for the modern Nilgiris. Built in May 1819, John Sullivan’s bungalow, a depleted structure, was reconstructed in 2002 by the then collector Supriya Sahu and was declared a tourist centre. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. Kovai Kuttralam falls to get facelift.description: Coimbatore: Soon, tourists to the Kovai Kuttralam falls near the city can take showers in the falls amid revamped facilities. The forest department is renovating the bathing areas and children’s pool. The structures at the bathing area had become old, department officials said. “The platforms were damaged due to constant flow of water. We are conducting repairs. We are also renovating the children’s pool,” an official said. “Almost 90% of the work is over. We have paused the works for the time as water flow has increased following the recent rain. We would soon divert the flow and resume the work.” The renovation work was done under the eco-tourism development activities. The eco-tourism department would release the funds after the forest department completes the work. Currently, tourists are barred from entering the falls as the works are ongoing. Also, the water is mixed with mud and stones following the fresh monsoon rain. “We would resume the construction work and finish it soon. Tourists will be allowed when the flow becomes even,” the official added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Space constraints delay setting up of pa.description: TIRUPUR: Due to non-availability of required space in post offices, the Union ministry of external affairs and department of posts are struggling to establish a post office passport seva kendra (POPSK) in the city. Under the Coimbatore regional passport office, POPSKs were already set up in Salem, Rasipuram, Erode and Coonoor. To further increase the efficiency in issuing passports, the external affairs ministry has planned to establish at least one POPSK in each parliamentary constituency. Two years ago, it proposed to set up 10 new centres, including in Tirupur, across the state. A postal officer on condition of anonymity said, “Such passport centres would be preferred to be set up in head post offices but Tirupur head post office is already congested with other postal services. So, we took steps to establish the centre at Tirupur collectorate post office. Since the collectorate is a state government building, it did not work out for investment from the central government.” “Though we have space in Avinashi post office, the MEA did not give green signal since Avinashi falls under the Nilgiris parliamentary constituency. The postal department has informed MEA that it has a vacant land on College Road in the dollar city and requested it to see whether it could be utilized for constructing a new building for Tirupur north post office-cum-POPSK,” the officer said. “The postal department also has consulted with the Tirupur district administration whether it could get required space for the centre in a new building constructed for integrated district courts complex inside the collectorate campus,” he added. An official from Coimbatore RPO said, “There should be around 400 sqft for POPSK, and we are looking out for the suitable place in Tirupur. We hope that we will find the space quickly and start the centre, which will cater services to the people from entire district.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Uttar Pradesh.description: "You're sitting on my grand mother's grave," Salim Shah told this correspondent. She has been buried, he said, in his living room. A clutch of houses in Chah Pokhar in Achnera block of Agra have turned into graveyards as families are forced to bury their departed in their homes due to lack of a burial ground. As a result, the dead here are a constant part of day-to-day life. TOI found women cooking next to where their children were buried while the elderly rested on cots in a backyard full of graves. In one of the houses, Rinki Begum told TOI that five bodies were buried in her backyard, including that of her 10-month-old son who had died of an untreated fever. Another resident, Guddi, said, "For poor people like us, there is no dignity in death. Due to lack of space in houses, people have to sit and walk over graves. It is so disrespectful." Almost all the houses in the block have graves within the compound Most of the Muslim families here are poor and landless and men scout for work as contract labourers. They said their demand for a graveyard has been ignored for years. The pond in Chah Pokhar village, where a piece of land is allocated for the burial ground on papersThe apathy of the administration can be gauged from the fact that a plot allotted for a graveyard some years ago falls right in the middle of a pond. Repeated complaints have fallen on deaf ears and residents are running out of space. The fresh graves are no more cemented to ensure they occupy less space and stones of different sizes kept over them are the only way to tell them apart. Protests have erupted in the past over the issue. In 2017, after the death of resident Mangal Khan, his family refused to bury his body until land for a graveyard was provided in the village. After assurances by the authorities, they buried Khan near the pond. But the promises came to nothing. Living with the dead: A grave in the backyard"All we are asking for is some land for our ancestors. There is a cremation ground for the Hindus in the periphery of the village, but we are living with our dead," said Munim Khan, a factory worker. Desperate residents even tried reaching out to nearby Sanan village and Achnera town that have burial grounds. But they were not willing to part with precious space. "These two villages have a larger Muslim population than Chah Pokhar. Their burial grounds are filled to capacity," said Nizam Khan, a mechanic. Village pradhan Sundar Kumar said that he had asked officials several times for a burial ground for Muslim families, but no action was taken. Ravi Kumar NG, the district magistrate, said that he was not aware of the issue. "I will send an official team to the village and get details of the burial land required." Farmers want permission to graze cattle.description: COIMBATORE: A group of cattle farmers from villages in and around Thondamuthur approached the Coimbatore district collector for permission to graze their cows in forestland again. They said the population of native cattle breeds, specifically the Malai Kongu Maadu, had dropped drastically after farmers were banned from grazing their cattle in reserve forest zones. They also demanded that the price at which Aavin buys A2 milk from farmers be raised to encourage more farmers to breed and maintain native cow breeds. Farmers, led by the Kongu Patteeshwaran Ghoshala, have requested the collector to make the forest department again issue “patti passes” to cattle farmers. “This is a pass that the forest department was issuing to allow us to graze our cattle in forest areas and lands. Around 2000-01, there were nearly 1.5 lakh to two lakh Malai Kongu cows in villages in and around Thondamuthur including Madhampatti, Karadimadai and Viraliyur,” said T Shanmugam a member of the Ghoshala. “However, in 2002, when the forest department withdrew our patti passes and banned our and our cattle’s entry into forest areas, many farmers panicked and sold thousands of their native cows to slaughterhouses. We hardly have a few thousand cows of the native breed left,” he said. The farmers said the government should incentivise rearing of native breeds of cattle. “While one way is to allow us to graze in forest areas, the other one is to make Aavin buy A2 milk from farmers for at least Rs 50 to Rs 60 per litre. They currently buy it for Rs 20 per litre, which is the cost for A1 milk. They have only one category called milk,” said Shanmugam. “They should also ban construction on hill area conservation lands and foothills of mountains, because it eventually takes away greenery and open lands which can be used for grazing,” he added. The cattle farmers said that the ban on cattle has affected their environment in multiple ways. “Whenever our cattle used to graze in the forest fringes, wild animals never came out of the forest. We have never seen wild elephants, bears and leopards. Now they have begun coming to our villages,” the petition said. “The cow’s urine and dung were so beneficial to the soil that the forests were thicker and they used to eat grass so well, that fresh grass kept growing. Now we have less greenery and temperature is higher. We have also had to start using chemical pesticides, because we don’t have enough cow urine to make biopesticides,” it said. Organic matter in farmland soil dipped,.description: COIMBATORE: The amount of organic matter in farmland soil has drastically come down in the state due to indiscriminate use of chemical pesticides and fertilisers, experts, who attended the state-level soil health card workshop organised by the state department of agriculture held at the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) here revealed on Monday. Due to indiscriminate use of chemical fertilisers and pesticides, microbes and earthworms were destroyed and the soil has become lifeless, said joint director of agriculture S Banumathi., who spoke at the inaugural function. “Crops cultivated in such soil don’t have good growth and fall prey to insects and diseases. Due to soil pollution and climate change, the organic nutrients of soil in the state, which was 1.26% in 1980, had come down to 0.68% in 2013-2014,” she said. “To compensate this, the health of the soil has to be analysed frequently and organic fertilisers have to be used.” During the Green Revolution, chemical fertilisers were used to increase production to cater to a growing population and health of the soil came down due to that, the experts said. “In today’s scenario of growing population and shrinking cultivable land area, productivity per unit cultivable area has to be increased,” said Azhagu Nagendran, deputy director of agriculture, Theni. “To address this issue, in 1995, the state had started the soil health card scheme as a pilot project in three districtsDharmapuri, Kanchipuram and Trichy. Under the scheme, soil nutrients in agricultural lands were tested and farmers were given booklets about soil health.” Under the renewed mission on soil health card, a part of the National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture, the state has been testing soil samples and giving soil health cards in two phases from 2016. A total of 30 soil testing laboratories and 16 mobile soil testing laboratories have been functioning across the state for the purpose. A total of 9.61lakh soil samples were tested in the two phases. TNAU vice-chancellor N Kumar said soil health management plays a major role in increasing productivity and reducing farmers’ expense. The workshop, which was attended by as many as 200 officials and 100 farmers from across the state, featured sessions on suitable fertiliser prescriptions, soil organic nutrient management and bio-fertilisers. No takers for textile inspection service.description: Tirupur: For more than a decade since globalisation, the central government’s textile committee was the quality regulating agency for all textile export goods in the country. But now, the committee’s inspection services have almost no takers in the textile industry. With around 30 offices across the country, the textiles committee which comes under the union textiles ministry, was functioning with many objectives. While hosting one of textile power centers, Tamil Nadu alone has six textiles committee offices, barring another one closed in Salem a year ago. More than 20 quality assurance officers were associated with the offices. “Earlier, one of the major goals was to regulate quality of all goods exported from textile units because the government wanted to ensure that the quality should not become an issue. But in 2004, the government took decision of leaving the quality as a matter between the foreign buyers and the exporters, so the mandatory regulation was dropped,” said a senior official associated with the textiles committee. However, the committee had started to offer inspection services as it can act as a third party between the buyers and the manufacturers. The committee has adequate infrastructure including textile labs and technically sound employees but do not have many takers. “We were not approached for the services by the industry despite having all the capacities. Many private quality assurance agencies filled up almost whole space of offering inspection services,” the official said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Coonoor river will be fenced to stop pol.description: UDHAGAMANDALAM: The Coonoor river would soon be fenced and CCTV cameras installed to monitor the area to prevent dumping of waste into it, collector J Innocent Divya said. She warned miscreants of a heavy fine if they indulge in such activities. The collector, who inaugurated a cleaning campaign at Coonoor bus stand on Wednesday, said encroachments of pavements and roads would be viewed very seriously and offenders would be punished. Every shopkeeper should place a bin at the entrance of the shop, she added. Later in the day, the collector presided over Jamabandhi meeting at Coonoor taluk office and received grievances from the public. She received as many as 230 petitions seeking bus service, old age pension, drinking water facility and road facilities. She ordered the concerned officials to take immediate action on the petitions. She also distributed benefits of government welfare schemes to be selected people. Govindarajan, a resident of Coonoor, said, “People who comes to Coonoor steps first into Coonoor bus stand. But it is always untidy. The Coonoor river is exposed to litters as it is located close to the bus stand.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Lok Sabha Poll 2019.description: LUCKNOW: With electioneering for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls gaining steam in Uttar Pradesh, political leaders are increasingly resorting to personal attacks on their adversaries. If the maverick BJP MLA from Bairia, Surendra Singh hit the headlines for his remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, Uttar Pradesh cabinet minister Shrikant Sharma hit a new low by making indecent comments on Congress chief Rahul Gandhi. The Bairia MLA had said Mayawati gets facials done and her hair coloured even though she is 60-years-old. He also reportedly made offensive remarks against UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi and Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Chaudhary, evoking widespread criticism from political parties and social media users. A media agency quoted him as saying that both Sonia Gandhi and Sapna Chaudhary used to work as dancers. "Rahul's mother (Sonia Gandhi) was also in the same profession in Italy and his father made her his own. He (Rahul Gandhi) should also take the family tradition forward and make Sapna his own," the MLA said. The BJP legislator, who is known for his controversial statements, had earlier termed Rahul Gandhi and his sister Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "Ravana and Shurpanakha", and accused Mayawati of "murdering" a woman's dignity by joining hands with one-time arch rival Samajwadi Party. UP Power Minister Shrikant Sharma stirred up a hornet's nest with his tweet terming the Congress president a "coward and impotent". The comments triggered a war of words between the two parties as well as on social media platform. Firebrand Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath also finds mention in the list of leaders accused of making personal remarks against political rivals. He recently termed Congress candidate from Saharanpur, Imran Masood, the son-in-law of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Azhar Masood. Addressing a rally in Saharanpur on Sunday, Adityanath said, "The son-in-law of Azhar Masood has entered the constituency and he speaks the language of the terror mastermind. "You people have to ensure that the person who speaks the language of Azhar Masood is defeated in the Lok Sabha elections," he said while seeking votes for BJP candidate from Saharanpur, Raghav Lakhanpal. Union minister and BJP MP Mahesh Sharma referred to Rahul Gandhi as 'Pappu' and his sister Priyanka Gandhi as 'Pappu ki Pappi' during a poll campaign in Gautam Buddh Nagar. Rahul Gandhi has often been mocked by the BJP and his opposition as 'Pappu', a colloquial sneer. "Pappu kehta hai main prime minister banunga Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu.. aur ab 'Pappu ki Pappi' bhi aa gayi hai. Wo Priyanka kya pehle hamare desh ki beti nahi thi kya, Congress ki beti nahi thi kya, aage nahi rahegi kya? kya naya leke aayi hai?" the minister told a crowd of his supporters on March 16. The quotes loosely translate to "Pappu says he wants to become prime minister. Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu ... and now 'Pappu's Pappi' has also arrived. Wasn't Priyanka already a daughter of this nation, a daughter of the Congress? And would she not remain so in future? What new has she brought in?" Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

BJP List 2019 WB.description: KOLKATA: The BJP in its first list of 28 candidates for West Bengal has pinned hopes on its veterans and defectors from the ruling Trinamool Congress to take on the Mamata Banerjee's government in the state. Of the 28 candidates, nearly 25 are new faces, with a thrust on active political workers rather than greenhorns from the glamour world. The saffron party, which bagged two Lok Sabha seats in the 2014 elections, is now targeting 23 of the state's 42 constituencies. BJP Lok Sabha first full listUnlike the TMC list, which had 18 new faces and a mix of both old-timers and greenhorns, hardcore politicians and personalities from the film industry, the BJP has put faith on its own leaders and defectors from other parties. There are four women candidates and one Muslim nominee in the first list. Of the candidates, five had recently defected to the saffron party from the Trinamool Congress and one from the CPI(M). West Bengal: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageUnion minister and BJP MP from Asansol Lok Sabha constituency Babul Supriyo has been renominated from the same seat and is pitted against actor Moon Moon Sen of the TMC. State BJP president Dilip Ghosh will contest from Medinipur seat against TMC leader Manas Bhunia. BJP national secretary Rahul Sinha will take on TMC heavyweight Sudip Bandopadhyay in Kolkata North Lok Sabha seat. State BJP vice-president and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose grandnephew, Chandra Kumar Bose will contest from Kolkata South Lok Sabha seat. Former IPS officer Bharati Ghosh, once known to be close to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, will be fighting against TMC candidate and actor Dipak Adhikary, popularly known as 'Dev', from Ghatal Lok Sabha constituency. The BJP has fielded former Trinamool Congress MLA Arjun Singh from Barrackpur Lok Sabha seat. Singh, who had recently joined the saffron party, has been pitted against TMCs Dinesh Trivedi. In Coochbebar Lok Sabha seat, the party has fielded former TMC youth leader Nishith Pramanik, while in Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, expelled TMC MP Anupam Hazra will contest against TMC's Mimi Chakraborty, an actor by profession. Another former TMC MP Soumitra Khan, who joined the BJP in January, has been given ticket from Bishnupur(SC) Lok Sabha seat. Former CPI(M) MLA Khagen Murmu, who too had switched over to the BJP, will contest from Malda North seat and will take on TMCs Mausam Benazir Noor, who had recently defected to the party from the Congress, in Malda Uttar seat. The Lok Sabha elections in the state will be held from April 11 till May 19 in seven phases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

2 men fined for killing wild boar.description: COIMBATORE: The forest department has imposed penalties worth Rs 40,000 against two people for killing a wild boar using a country-made bomb at Periyanaickenpalayam on the city outskirts of the city on Sunday. The accused were identified as P Kumar, 38, a resident of Gudalur Kavundampalayam and M Arumugam, 51, of Thirumalainaickenpalayam. A team led by forest department ranger Suresh had apprehended the duo while conducting patrol near Naickar Garden, a patta land, around 10:30pm on Sunday. The men were carrying a bag. “Investigation revealed that they had killed a wild boar using a country-made bomb. They were carrying the wild meat,”an official said. The accused were booked under the wildlife protection Act. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election.
